cummins package

Submodules

cummins.approximate_gpr module

Approximate GP models

Author: Ilias Bilionis

class cummins.approximate_gpr.ApproximateModel1(dim, num_inputs, window_size, causal_dim, output_dim, inducing_points=10)[source]

Bases: ApproximateGP

Create simple Gaussian process with a constant mean and an RBF kernel using approximate inference.

Demonstrate how math can be used in the docstring:

\(f(x) \sim \mathcal{GP}(m(x), k(x, x'))\)

\(m(x) = c\)

\(k(x, x') = \sigma^2 \exp(- \frac{1}{2} (x - x')^T \Lambda (x - x'))\)

Demonstrate how to use a code block in the docstring:

def hello_world():
    print("Hello, world!")
forward(x)[source]

Forward pass through the model.

inspect_parameters()[source]

Print information about the parameters of the model.

class cummins.approximate_gpr.ApproximateModel2(dim, num_inputs, window_size, causal_dim, output_dim, inducing_points=10)[source]

Bases: ApproximateGP

Same as ApproximateModel1 but with a linear mean.

forward(x)[source]

Defines the computation performed at every call.

Should be overridden by all subclasses.

Note

Although the recipe for forward pass needs to be defined within this function, one should call the Module instance afterwards instead of this since the former takes care of running the registered hooks while the latter silently ignores them.

inspect_parameters()[source]

Print information about the parameters of the model.

class cummins.approximate_gpr.ApproximateModel_SVDKL(dim, num_inputs, window_size, causal_dim, output_dim, inducing_points)[source]

Bases: Module

Approximate Gaussian Process with Deep Kernel.

Adapted from the following GPytorch tutorial: https://docs.gpytorch.ai/en/stable/examples/06_PyTorch_NN_Integration_DKL/Deep_Kernel_Learning_DenseNet_CIFAR_Tutorial.html

cummins.ecdf_scaler module

A scaler class that uses the empirical cummulative distribution function.

Author: Ilias Bilionis

class cummins.ecdf_scaler.ECDFScaler[source]

Bases: object

A class that scales by using the empirical CDF of the data.

fit(data: ndarray[Any, dtype[_ScalarType_co]]) → ECDFScaler[source]

Compute the ECDF of the data to be used for later scaling.

I got the idea from this question: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/44132543/python-inverse-empirical-cumulative-distribution-function-ecdf

fit_transform(data: ndarray[Any, dtype[_ScalarType_co]]) → ndarray[Any, dtype[_ScalarType_co]][source]

Fit to data, then transform it.

inverse_transform(data_scaled: ndarray[Any, dtype[_ScalarType_co]]) → ndarray[Any, dtype[_ScalarType_co]][source]
transform(data_original: ndarray[Any, dtype[_ScalarType_co]]) → ndarray[Any, dtype[_ScalarType_co]][source]

Scales original data to R

cummins.numpyro_models module

Author: Maxwell Bolt

Numpyro Bayesian Neural Network Model From example: https://num.pyro.ai/en/stable/examples/bnn.html

cummins.numpyro_models.create_sliding_window(input_data, output_data, window_size)[source]
cummins.numpyro_models.jnp_model1(X, Y, D_H, D_Y=1)[source]

BNN using numpyro

cummins.numpyro_models.jnp_model2(X, Y, D_H, D_Y=1)[source]

BNN using numpyro, outputs 2 values to form the mean and covariance of a normal for the likelihood.

cummins.numpyro_models.jnp_predict(model, rng_key, samples, X, D_H)[source]

Predicts the output of the model given samples from the posterior

cummins.numpyro_models.jnp_run_inference(model, rng_key, X, Y, D_H, num_chains=1, num_warmup=1000, num_samples=1000)[source]

Runs NUTS on the numpyro model.

cummins.pyro_models module

Author: Maxwell Bolt

class cummins.pyro_models.BLR(in_features, out_features)[source]

Bases: PyroModule

Performs simple Bayesian linear regression with a standard Normal prior on weight.
